fields.descriptive_line: Theatrical ensemble, coat, waistcoat, trousers and slippers, worn by Henry Irving as Digby Grant in Two Roses by James Albery, 1870, Act I.
fields.physical_description:
[coat] Chestnut wool jacket lined with purple wool, with wide reveres and  three decorative self-covered. buttons (not practicable). Two pockets.
[waistcoat] Purple/brown waistcoat patterned with alternate vertical stripes of velvet and silk woven with roses. Two slit pockets. Dark brown cotton sateen panels at back, faced with pale brown wool, with buckle to adjust width. Buckle stamped 'Paris'. Tailor's label for 'Kerslake, 12 Hanover St.' sewn to strap of buckle.
[trousers] Beige twill weave trousers, lined inside waist with cream cotton striped in red and green. Fly fastening with four metal buttons stamped 'Kerslake, 12 Hanover St.'. Six further metal buttons on waistband for braces. Two front pockets, each fastened with horn (or plastic) buttons. Strap across back waist fastened with buckle stamped 'Paris'. A strap to go underneath the foot is attached by a button inside the lower hem of each trouser leg.
[slipper] One of a pair of maroon slippers. The canvas base decorated with needlepoint and beading. Body of slipper covered with cross stitch in maroon wool and a pattern of mutlicoloured beading on the front of the shoe and round the sides. The beads are in various shades of blue, pink, brown and white. Edges bound in a dark velvet which has almost completely lost its pile. Flat leather sole. Lined in green quilted silk, much of this covering is now become detached and discoloured.
[slipper] One of a pair of maroon slippers. The canvas base decorated with needlepoint and beading. Body of slipper covered with cross stitch in maroon wool and a pattern of mutlicoloured beading on the front of the shoe and round the sides. The beads are in various shades of blue, pink, brown and white. Edges bound in a dark velvet which has almost completely lost its pile. Flat leather sole. Lined in green quilted silk, much of this covering is now become detached and discoloured.
fields.dimensions:
[coat] Length: 84 cm maximum, Width: 47 cm measured across shoulders, Width: 46 cm measured across chest
[waistcoat] Length: 57 cm maximum, Width: 41 cm measured across shoulders, Width: 45 cm measured across chest
[trousers] Length: 122.5 cm maximum, Width: 41 cm meausured across waist, Length: 114 cm outside leg
[slipper] Length: 29 cm sole, Height: 6 cm from base of sole to top of heel
[slipper] Length: 29 cm, Height: 6 cm
fields.materials_techniques:
[coat] Wool
[waistcoat] Velvet, silk and cotton sateen.
fields.marks:
[waistcoat] 'J. KERSLAKE & Co. / 12 HANOVER ST, HANOVER SQ. / No.'
[waistcoat] 'H. Irving Esq'
[trousers] 'J. KERSLAKE & Co. / 12 HANOVER ST, HANOVER SQ. / No.'
[trousers] 'L 34 ½  W34¼ / Hy Irving Esq'
fields.public_access_description:
Henry Irving (1838-1905) wore this costume as Digby Grant in Act One of the comedy Two Roses, by James Albery (1838 - 1889), produced at London's Vaudeville Theatre in 1870.  

Grant is an impecunious 'distressed' gentleman, living in a rural cottage with his daughters Ida and Lottie - the "roses" of the title.  When the inheritance of an estate restores Digby's prosperity he forbids his daughters to encourage their admirers whom he now thinks socially inferior.  In Act Three news arrives that the correct beneficiary is not Digby but Lottie's beloved Caleb Deecie, causing, her father to accept both his daughters' sweethearts as suitors.  

The cut and style of this costume reflect Digby's circumstances in financial adversity.

Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learned his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  He joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman in 1871, winning great acclaim that year for his psychologically developed characterisation of the guilt-ridden inn-keeper Mathias in Leopold Lewis's melodrama The Bells.  He took on the responsibilities of 'actor-manager' in 1878 when he assumed the management of the Lyceum, and remained there until 1902, enjoying star status with his leading lady Ellen Terry (1847-1928).   Irving produced a diverse range of old and new plays at the Lyceum, including Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  His tireless work to elevate the status of the theatrical profession was rewarded in 1895 when he became the first actor ever to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Irving specialised in spectacularly staged productions with large casts of performers. He commissioned designers and composers to create appropriate scenery, costume and incidental music, played by a full orchestra.  Although electric lighting was available from the 1880s, Irving preferred the softer effects of gas, with lime light to focus attention at key points in the play.  Irving toured complete productions outside London, taking the full company, scenery and costumes throughout the United Kingdom and across the United States and Canada.   The development of the railway system made his the first generation able to achieve this level of touring productions.
fields.bibliography: Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 18.
fields.historical_context_note: Museum of London note: 'The play was later revived in 1882.'
